questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The above image shows Walsham's forceps. Walsham forceps are mainly used to reduce the nasal bone fracture.

Other options:

  • Tilley’s forceps are used for nasal packing, ear dressing, removal of foreign bodies from the nose. It has a box joint.

questions.text: During the ophthalmology postings of your internship, you notice the following instrument being used by one of the senior resident. This instrument could be used to

choices.text: Test the color vision of patients
Refine the power and axis of cylindrical lens
Measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria
To visualize the angle of anterior chamber

questions.solution:
The given image shows Jackson’s cross cylinder (flip-cross technique), which is used to refine the power and axis of the cylindrical lens during refraction.

Other options:

Option A: Nagel’s anomaloscope given below is used to tests color vision.

Option C: Maddox rod consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. Maddox rod test is a macular function test used to measure the degree of heterotropia or heterophoria in cases of torsional diplopia.

Option D: Angle of the anterior chamber is visualized with the help of a gonioscope and slit lamp. The image given below shows goniolens used for gonioscopic examination.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Bohler Braun Splint?

choices.text: The proximal pulley prevents foot drop.
The fourth pulley applies traction in the line of the ipsilateral hip joint.
The second pulley is to apply traction in the line of the femur.
It can also be used for the fractured shaft of the tibia and fibula.

questions.solution:
The fourth pulley applies traction in the line of the legs.

Bohler Braun splint: This refers to Bohler’s modification of the Braun splint. It consists of a heavy metal frame with four pulleys. The respective functions of the pulleys are:

  1. The proximal pulley prevents foot drop.
  2. The second pulley is to apply traction in the line of the femur.
  3. The third pulley is to apply traction in the line of the supracondylar area of the femur.
  4. The fourth pulley applies traction in the line of the legs.

 

It is used for the treatment of fracture shaft femur and supracondylar fractures of the femur. It can also be used for the fractured shaft of the tibia and fibula.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used in a patient with severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Device 2 shown in the above image represents a cochlear implant, which can be used in a patient with bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss.

A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve, which bypasses the damaged hearing apparatus. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Cochlear implant:

  • An electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid.
  • Principle- surgery to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea.
  • Indication- bilateral severe to profound deafness
  • Prerequisites- intact 8th nerve and higher auditory pathway
  • Surgical approach- facial recess (posterior tympanotomy) approach
  • The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. (Note: In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.)

The receiver-stimulator implanted during surgery (under the skin) and the electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are part of the internal component of the cochlear implant. Microphone, speech processor, and transmitter are part of the external component of the cochlear implant, which remains outside the body.

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of the cochlea and convert the sound signal to electrical impulses, which directly stimulate the fibers of cranial nerve VIII.


Other options: 

Device 1 is a picture of a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA), which can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia. Bilateral aural atresia presents with failed audiological testing and requires early bone conduction hearing aids, one of which is BAHA, that combines a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear and allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear – a process known as direct bone conduction.

It consists of three parts:

  • An innermost titanium fixture in the bone
  • A middle abutment 
  • An outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment

Bone-anchored Hearing Aids are used:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal are associated with discharge and cannot wear standard “in the ear” air-conduction hearing aids.
    • Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals as in microtia or canal atresia.
  • In Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated
  • In Single-sided deafness

Device 3 is a picture of a stapedectomy piston, used in patients with otosclerosis.

Device 4 is a picture of a partial ossicular replacement prosthesis that is designed for situations when the incus and/or malleus are eroded but the stapes is structurally intact.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and pain in the right eye. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. A procedure incorporates the following device to aid drainage and treat this condition. Identify the device.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma and the device used is an Ex-Press glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

Ex-Press glaucoma implant (mini shunt), is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap during a modified trabeculectomy. Mitomycin c might be used to prevent scarring. Complications such as hypotony are lower as compared to standard trabeculectomy.

 

Glaucoma drainage devices: They are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing a communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. 

The commonly used devices are as follows:

  • Shunts using episcleral explants

    • Ahmed glaucoma valve: A valved implant consisting of a silicone tube connected to a silicone sheet valve held together in a polypropylene body. It has a venturi valve mechanism that allows for an immediate decrease in IOP and reduced post-operative complications such as hypotony. 

    • Molteno implant: One or two polypropylene plates connected to a silicone tube. It has a larger surface area and provides long-term IOP reduction. However, risk of post-operative hypotony is high. 

    • Baerveldt implant: Large silicone plate connected to a silicone tube. It is easy to modify, flexible, and easy to implant. However, it is a bulky device and post-operative hypotony and scar deformation are associated risks. 

  • Mini-shunts 

    • Ex-Press Mini-Shunt

    • iStent®: It is a hooked titanium tube inserted into the Schlemm canal via the trabecular meshwork. More than one istent can be implanted a the same time for better control of the intraocular pressure.

The images below show the Ahmed and Molteno implants respectively.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child diagnosed with bronchial asthma requires bronchodilator therapy. Which of the following device will you prescribe for this child, to avoid oropharyngeal adverse effects?
questions.solution:
The device in image 3 is a spacer device that can be prescribed to decrease the incidence of propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug depositing in the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drugs inhaled into the lower airways. Thus, a less amount of the drug gets swallowed and absorbed from the GI tract and limits local side effects. 

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.


The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

Pressurized metered-dose inhalers (pMDI) - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and can deliver 50–200 doses of a drug.

Image 1 in the question stem shows a pressurized metered-dose inhaler.


Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children below 7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 

Image 2 in the question stem shows a dry powder inhaler.


Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -

  • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
  • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

Image 4 in the question stem shows a nebulizer.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below and the procedure it is used for.
questions.solution:
The given instrument shows the Jamshidi needle. It is used for bone marrow biopsy. 

Jamshidi needles have a t-bar at the end for easier maneuvering. Jamshidi needle has a tapering end to reduce the crush artifacts in the sample.

Indications of bone marrow biopsy:

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia.
  • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis.
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors.
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias.
  • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases.
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections or granulomatous diseases.

Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy: 

  • Severe hemophilia.
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • Severe bleeding disorders.

Other options:

Option B: The image below shows a cutting-type vim Silverman liver biopsy needle.

Option C: Veress Needle is used to produce a pneumoperitoneum in direct puncture laparoscopy.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger. Because the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or penetrating a towel clip to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures.

Option D: Salah's needles are reusable bone marrow biopsy needles, made up of stainless steel.

questions.text: A 58-year-old post-menopausal lady comes to you with a DEXA report showing a T-score of -2.8 SD. Which of the following braces can be used to prevent pathological vertebral fractures in her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with a T score of - 2.8SD is suggestive of Osteoporosis. 2 braces that can be used in the prophylactic bracing of the spine for the prevention of pathological vertebral fractures are the Anterior spinal hyperextension braces (ASHE) brace and the Taylor brace.

Taylor brace - It is indicated for stabilization of the spine in dorsolumbar spinal injury. It is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support the spine while standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.


ASHE brace - ASHE brace is an anterior spinal hyperextension brace used in dorsolumbar spinal injury. A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending.


Scoliosis can also be managed with the Boston brace which is a type of thoracic-lumbar-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). 

The image given below shows the Boston brace:

 

Milwaukee brace - Milwaukee brace can be used for the management of Scoliosis and kyphosis. Also known as cervico-thoraco-lumbosacral orthosis or CTLSO, it is a back brace used in the treatment of spinal curvatures (such as scoliosis or kyphosis) in children. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. It is still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine.

The image shown below is the Milwaukee brace.


SOMI Brace - The Sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization (SOMI) brace is used for cervical spine injury. It may also be used as a recovery aid following cervical spine surgery.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument given in the image is Eves’ tonsil snare. 

Eves’ tonsil snare is used for tonsillectomy and the wire used is number 25 SWG. After the tonsil has been dissected to its lower pole, the snare is passed around the tonsil to engage the pedicle and then firmly closed. It crushes and cuts the pedicle thereby minimizing bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Negus knot tier is also an instrument that is used in tonsillectomy.  It helps to carry the ligature knot till the tip of the artery forceps which holds the vessel and then tie it.


Option B: Tonsil dissector and anterior pillar retractor - Dissection of the tonsil is done by one end and the other end serves to retract the anterior pillar for inspecting the tonsillar fossa to locate any bleeding points.


Option C: Denis Browne’s tonsil holding forceps is used to hold the tonsil during dissection method tonsillectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for the surgery in which the following instrument is used?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a myringotome and myringotomy/tympanostomy is done by a sharp myringotome. An intratympanic glomus tumor is a contraindication for myringotomy.

Myringotomy refers to the incision made on the tympanic membrane with the purpose to drain suppurative or nonsuppurative effusion of the middle ear or to provide aeration in case of a malfunctioning eustachian tube.

Indications of myringotomy:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media and its complications
  • Recurrent acute otitis media
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the Eustachian tube)
  • Atelectatic ear (treated along with grommet insertion)

Contraindication of myringotomy: It is contraindicated in suspected cases of intratympanic glomus tumor, as it can cause profuse bleeding in such patients.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows Ewald’s tube used in the gastric lavage.

Gastric lavage has been used to manage toxic ingestions for a long time. It is indicated in unprotected airway, seizures, and the need for urgent removal of toxic substances. 

Contraindications for this procedure include insignificant ingestions, prolonged time since ingestion, and caustic poisoning. Activated charcoal is usually given after lavage.

Complications include nasal trauma, esophageal perforation, tracheal intubation, aspiration, and hypothermia. 

The following image shows Ewald's tube.

 

Other options-

Option A: Ryle's tube (nasogastric tube) is indicated in intestinal obstruction and nutritional support. 

 

Option C- Sengstaken Blakemore tube is used for balloon tamponade in case of hemorrhage due to esophageal varices. 

 

Option D- Kehr's T tube is used to stent and drain the bile duct after choledochotomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the casualty following an RTA. X-Rays taken show the presence of a fracture of the femoral shaft.  Which of the following implants will the orthopedic surgeon use in this case?
questions.solution:
Among the given nails used as implants, image 3 shows a Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K nail), which is used for the treatment of femoral fractures.

It is based on the concept of three-point fixation i.e., at either end and at the isthmus. The eye at the end of the nail is useful while removing it. The Cloverleaf shape on the cross-section provides good rotational stability.

Some common complications of K-nailing:

  • Nail getting stuck
  • Splintering of the cortex while hammering the nail
  • Proximal migration of the nail, leading to bursitis over its protruding end
  • Distal migration of the nail leading to stiffness of the knee
  • Infection

Other options :

Image 1 shows the Smith Petersen nail (SP nail), used for internal fixation of femoral neck fracture.

Smith Petersen nail (SP nail):

It is a cannulated triflanged nail that is used for internal fixation of a fracture of the neck of the femur. Advantages of its triflanged shape:

  • It prevents axial rotation of the fragments
  • It cuts only a little bone to provide good stability.

The nail is cannulated because it is threaded over a guide wire introduced at the correct site under X-ray control. It can be used along with McLaughlin’s plate for the fixation of inter-trochanteric fractures as well.

Image 2 shows Ender’s nail. This is used for internal fixation of intertrochanteric fractures of the femur.

Image 3 shows Talwalkar's square nail. This is used for fractures of forearm bones.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: The device shown below is the most widely used instrument for measuring  _______.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a dry and wet bulb hygrometer. It is the most widely used instrument for measuring the humidity of air. 

A dry and wet bulb hygrometer consists of two identical thermometers—a dry bulb thermometer and a wet-bulb thermometer—mounted side by side on a stand. 

After obtaining the readings of both thermometers, the corresponding relative humidity can be found in psychrometric charts and slides. 

Other instruments used to measure humidity:

  • Sling psychrometer
  • Assmann psychrometer

Other options:

Option B - The mean radiant temperature is measured using a globe thermometer.

Option C - The cooling power of air was originally measured using a kata thermometer. Kata thermometer is now largely used for recording low air velocities. 

Option D - The maximum temperature reached in a given time is measured by a maximum thermometer. The thermometer is set each time by swinging briskly.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A young man falls on an outstretched hand and develops a fracture as shown in the X-ray below.  Which of the following screws is commonly used to treat this fracture?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray and the history of falls on the outstretched hands suggest the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture. Herbert screw is commonly used to treat this fracture.

Herbert screw is a cannulated variable pitch screw, which is used to fix unstable or displaced fractures of small articular bones such as the scaphoid. This screw helps in quick healing by providing compression at the fracture site and early return to normal activities. The advantage of cannulated screws is that we can use a guidewire under videofluoroscopy to assist in the accurate placement of the screw during surgery.

Scaphoid fractures occur most commonly after a fall on an outstretched hand. The waist of the scaphoid is the most common site of fracture. Initial x-rays are done in anteroposterior, lateral, and oblique views. Even if the x-rays appear normal, if there is clinical suspicion, a glass holding cast should be applied for 2 weeks followed by repeat imaging.

Management depends upon the type of fracture. If the scaphoid tubercle is fractured, the patient is given a glass-holding cast for 4-6 weeks. In case of undisplaced waist fractures, most people will recover with a cast in place for 6-8 weeks. Percutaneous screw fixation with the Herbert screw can be offered to those with displaced or undisplaced fractures of the waist when the patient does not want to undergo prolonged cast immobilization, or if they wish to return to work/daily activities sooner. Reducing and fixing displaced fractures also reduces the risk of non-union.

The most common complications include nonunion, avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of the proximal fracture segment, and osteoarthritis. 

Herbert screw is shown below:

 

Other options:

Option A: Cannulated cancellous screws are commonly used to treat fractures of the neck of the femur.

Option B: The interference screw is a biodegradable screw used during anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction. This screw is made of polymers that increase its strength so as to improve cortical bone formation at the site as well as to ensure that the tibial tunnel is not too wide during the insertion of the newly reconstructed ligament.

Option D: Pedicle screws are used in spinal fusion surgery to provide added strength and support. They are placed above and below the vertebrae that were fused. Rods are used to connect the screws, which prevent their movement and allow the bone to heal. They are also used in the correction of scoliosis.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: The equipment shown below is used for the sterilization of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows an autoclave.  It is not used to sterilize endoscopes because most of them are heat-sensitive. 

Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization using steam under pressure. The temperature is kept between 108oC to 147oC. It is used to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

Endoscopes are cleaned using liquid chemical sterilizing agents such as orthophthaldehyde as it has bactericidal properties and is quick, safe and effective.`

Other equipments used in sterilization include:

Hot air oven- The objects undergo a holding period of 160oC for two hours to sterilize glassware, forceps, scissors, scalpels, swabs, and some pharmaceutical products such as liquid paraffin, dusting powder.

 

UV sterilization: Ultraviolet radiation is used to disinfect enclosed areas mainly biosafety cabinets in laboratories, operation theatres, and laboratories. The given image shows UV sterilization in a biosafety cabinet.

 

Incineration : Terminal sterilisation for destroying biomedical waste such as human anatomical waste and plastics such as PVC and polythene.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of an enucleation spoon. This is identified by the central cleavage that engages the optic nerve in enucleation.

 

Other options:

Option A- Evisceration spatula consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle. It is used to separate out the uveal tissue from the sclera during evisceration operation.

 

Option C- Chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. The tip of one limb is flattened in the
form of a round disc while the tip of the other arm has a small circular ring. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation.

 

Option D- Bone punch consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during
dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

questions.text:
Match the following splints and the conditions where they are used.
  1. Cervical spine injury
  2. Brachial plexus injury
  3. Radial nerve palsy
  4. Ulnar nerve palsy
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

  1. Knuckle bender splint - Ulnar nerve palsy
  2. Cock-up splint  - Radial nerve palsy
  3. Aeroplane splint - Brachial plexus injury
  4. SOMI Brace - Cervical spine injury

Knuckle bender splint :

In cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated, the knuckle bender splint can be used to correct and prevent MCP (metacarpophalangeal) hyperextension.

Cock-up splint - 

it is used in the management of radial nerve palsy.

Aeroplane splint:

It is used in the management of brachial plexus injury and axillary nerve injury.

SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is used to treat cervical spine injury. 

It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. The SOMI brace may be used as a treatment for cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed after cervical spine surgery as a recovery aid.

questions.text: The apparatus shown below is used to estimate:
questions.solution:
The given image is that of Horrock’s apparatus which is used to determine the chlorine demand of water.

It consists of:

  • 6 white cups of 200 ml each
  • 1 black cup with a circular mark inside
  • 2 metal spoons -each holds 2g of bleaching powder
  • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
  • Two droppers
  • Starch-iodide indicator solution

The dose of bleaching powder required for disinfection of water can be calculated using this apparatus.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A patient presenting with cola-colored urine and abdominal pain was investigated to find out the cause. The following instrument was used in the definitive diagnosis of the patient's condition. Which disease this patient is most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a flow cytometry tube, which is used for diagnosing paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is due to acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA) leading to deficiency of GPI-linked proteins.PIGA is X-linked.

PNH blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity. They are : 

  • Decay-accelerating factor, or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis, or CD59
  • C8-binding protein.

Red cells deficient in GPI-linked factors are abnormally susceptible to lysis or injury by complement.

Clinical features of PNH:

  • Intravascular hemoglobinuria - cola-colored urine
  • Pancytopenia + hypercellular bone marrow
  • Thrombosis (if hepatic vein involved → Budd–Chiari syndrome)

Diagnosis:

  • HAM’S test (acidified serum lysis)
  • Sucrose lysis test
  • Flow cytometry: It is the gold standard for the diagnosis of PNH. It detects red cells that are deficient in GPI-linked proteins such as CD59 and CD55.

Eculizumab is used to alleviate the hemolysis associated with PNH and its sequelae. Eculizumab does not alter the underlying defect of the disease.
